title: 114_s1600
content: The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries, allowing covered persons to bring civil actions against agencies for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Act. These civil remedies are exclusive and subject to the same rights and limitations as individuals under the Privacy Act. The Privacy Act remedies are extended to covered persons under the Judicial Redress Act of 2015, allowing civil actions for intentional disclosures. Covered persons have the same rights and limitations as individuals under the Privacy Act when pursuing civil remedies. The Attorney General, with the concurrence of other officials, may designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if it has an agreement with the United States for privacy protections. The Attorney General can designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if it has an agreement with the United States for privacy protections or if it effectively shares information with the US for preventing criminal offenses. The designation can be removed with the concurrence of other officials. The Attorney General can revoke the designation of a foreign country as a "covered country" if it fails to comply with the agreement for sharing information to prevent criminal offenses or hinders the transfer of information to the United States by private entities. The Attorney General determines designated federal agencies for information exchange to prevent unlawful activity, requiring concurrence from relevant agency heads. The Attorney General designates federal agencies for information exchange with covered countries based on agreements or law enforcement interests. Determinations made under this section are published in the Federal Register and are not subject to review. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia has exclusive jurisdiction over any claim arising under this section. Definitions in this Act include terms like "agency," "covered country," "covered person," and "covered record." The term "covered person" refers to a non-individual citizen of a covered country. A "covered record" for a covered person is defined similarly to a record for an individual under section 552a of title 5, once transferred to a designated Federal agency for criminal investigation purposes. The term "individual" is defined in section 552a(a)(2) of title 5, United States Code. The Act does not waive privileges or require disclosure of classified information. The Act will take effect 90 days after enactment.
